content.title: Vascular Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome (Type IV)
content.summary: The most severe form of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, caused by COL3A1 mutations affecting type III collagen, leading to spontaneous arterial dissection, rupture, and bowel perforation with extremely fragile tissues.

definitions.definition: Autosomal dominant disorder caused by COL3A1 mutations, characterized by thin translucent skin, easy bruising, and catastrophic arterial rupture without aneurysmal dilation.
Diagnostic criteria requiring major criteria: thin translucent skin with visible veins, arterial rupture, bowel rupture, uterine rupture, or family history of vEDS.

key_concepts.explanation: Unlike other aortopathies, vEDS vessels do not dilate before rupturing. Arteries appear normal on imaging then suddenly dissect or rupture. Medium-sized vessels (iliac, splenic, hepatic, renal) are commonly affected.

Tissues are extremely fragile, making surgery technically challenging with high complication rates. Conservative management is preferred when possible. If surgery is necessary, buttressed sutures and reinforcing materials are essential.

The BBEST trial showed celiprolol (cardioselective beta-blocker with vasodilatory properties) reduced cardiovascular events by 64% over 5 years. This is the only medication with proven benefit in vEDS.
Spontaneous bowel perforation occurs in 25% of patients. Sigmoid colon is most commonly affected. Uterine rupture during pregnancy carries 15% maternal mortality.

evidence.citation: Ong et al., BBEST Trial, Lancet, 2010
evidence.finding: Celiprolol reduced arterial rupture, dissection, and death by 64% in vEDS patients

evidence.citation: Pepin et al., Natural History Study, NEJM, 2000
evidence.finding: Median survival 48-51 years; 80% of patients have major complication by age 40

clinical_pearls: Invasive procedures including angiography carry significant risk - use non-invasive imaging whenever possible
Do not rely on aneurysm formation - vEDS arteries rupture without warning at normal diameters
Skin findings (thin, translucent with visible veins, easy bruising) are diagnostic clues
Pregnancy is contraindicated by many experts due to uterine rupture risk
If surgery is required, use pledgeted sutures and avoid tension on tissues
learning_objectives: Distinguish vascular EDS from other connective tissue disorders
Explain why traditional aneurysm surveillance fails in vEDS
State the evidence for celiprolol therapy in vEDS
Describe surgical principles for operating on vEDS patients
Counsel vEDS patients about pregnancy risks
